docs.title: Capabilities
docs.text:
• Spinning disk confocal unit optimized for high resolution imaging
  • Four lasers (405nm, 488nm, 561nm, 640nm)
  • Live-cell imaging (5% CO2 and temperature control)
  • Dual cameras for simultaneous two-channel confocal imaging
  • Inverted Nikon Ti2-E with Perfect Focus System for eliminating focus drift
  • Motorized stage and z-piezo stage allow for tiling/stitching and fast z-stacks
  • Selective photoactivation/photobleaching with a 405nm laser

Check fluorophore performance on FPbase

docs.title: Calibration
docs.text:
The Galvo XY unit needs to be calibrated before use, but you can save/load calibration files for future use. Different calibration files are needed between single-cam and dual cam modes.

Currently, we should have calibration files for the 60x (single-cam) and 100x (single-cam and dual cam) objectives (at 37C). These calibration files should be accurate for the lower mag objectives, but since no one's FRAPing with them, it's been low on my priority list to check.

docs.title: How to calibrate (text)
docs.text:
1. Load a slide with a fluorophore able to be bleached or activated with a 405nm laser.
    • For 60x/100x objectives, reasonably confluent cell monolayers with autofluorescence works.
  2. Select a FRAP OC (or move the upper turret such that the 405-FRAP filtercube is in place)
    • Change the bit-depth to 16-bit to avoid oversaturation.
    • Set exposure time to something short like 50ms
  3. Uncheck the camera ROI
    • N.B.: The calibration must be done without any camera ROI selected.
  4. Open the "Galvy XY" window and set laser power to something like 1.5%
  5. Open Galvo XY settings by clicking on the gear icon
  6. Set "Volts low" to -1.5 and "Volts high" to 1.5
  7. Press "Calibrate"
    • Use "Toggle (Reflect laser)" instead of "Manual (Bleach point)"
    • Check the box for "Invert Y Axis" while making sure that "Invert X Axis" is unchecked
  8. Choose spots for the laser to go to and then tell the software where the center of the spot is.
    • Click on a spot in any quadrant while remaining somewhat close to the center until you get a sense for how far away you can go
      • If your chosen spot is within the camera ROI, you should see a bright spot in the Live view
    • Move the red cross to the center of the focused laser point.
      • Set the LUT settings appropriately--the buttons for autoscaling LUT may come in handy.
      • Make sure you zoom in to be sure you're choosing the right pixel.
    • When satisfied that the red cross is in the center, press the + symbol within the Galvo XY to add
    • Repeat until the usable field of view is well sampled. Aim for at least 12 throughout the rectangular FOV.
  9. Hit "Next" when satisfied and test by drawing an ROI and stimulating it.

docs.title: Why is this necessary?
docs.text:
Images on the two cameras will not be perfectly registered and will require an affine transformation.

To determine the location-dependent deviation, we need to image something that can be seen in each channel.

docs.title: Bead slide vs using spinning disk pinholes
docs.text:
Previously, we used a multi-color TetraSpeck bead slide, but this has some downsides:

  • Weak fluorescence and poor photostability → Annoying to use when doing coarse alignment
  • Uneven bead distribution → can take time to find a good bead region
  • New slides need to be made monthly → Extra effort

However, our 60x and 100x objectives are excellent and exhibit less than 100nm axial chromatic shift within the green, red, and far-red channels at 37C--far below the axial resolution of our scope. With this in mind, stopping the spinning disk's rotation and using transmitted light is a good and easy alternative.

docs.title: Aligning with spinning disk pinholes
docs.text: YouTube videos for aligning with pinholes

docs.title: Aligning with TetraSpeck beads
docs.text:
• Focus onto TetraSpeck beads, enable PFS, and start a timelapse for about 30 minutes
  • 30 minutes should be sufficient for temperatures to stabilize (as evidenced by no more drifting)
  • Load the relevant two-color OC (e.g. align-488-561)
  • Go Live and inspect the overlap of the 488 and 561 channels

Note

  • Aim for perfect overlap in the center of the ROI
  • The chromatic aberration will get worse at the edges of the FOV
  • If adjustments need to be made, use the 1.5mm hex screw. Translate the 488 channel by tweaking "H" and "V"1.

Tip

  • Compensate for the slight movement as you remove the hex screw.
  • When satisfied, acquire a multi-channel z-stack of the beads in order to align channels later. Make sure the beads are well distributed and extend to the edges of your FOV.

  1. Rotating the DM here leads to lateral translatation ↩

docs.title: Brightfield checklist
docs.text:
• Make sure that the condenser is set to the correct position for the objective
    • See the "Condenser for DIC" column
  • Make sure everything (including your slide) along the lightpath is clean / free of dust
    • If using DIC, use the air puffer to blow dust off the polarizer.
  • Perform Kohler Alignment using the 10x objective
    • See the Nikon guide for step-by-step instructions
  • DIC only: Make sure the objective-specific DIC slider is inserted
  • If using DIC, slide the polarizer in the lightpath. Otherwise keep it empty.

TwinCam DM severely reduces light throughput

If doing single camera acquisitions, make sure the TwinCam DM is removed.

docs.title: ROI
docs.text:
• The CSU-X1 limits the field of view to a max of 7x10mm. With a 100x objective and no other sources of magnification, the field of view roughly corresponds to 70um by 100um.
  • Saved camera ROIs are saved in the Documents folder and can be loaded by clicking on the "ROI Size" button and pressing "Load ROI..."

Laser illumination is not even across the field of view

  • If you care about intensity measurements or will be using intensities for thresholding, include a "flat field correction" processing step.
  • If acquiring tiled images, consider using the multipoints tab for grid selection and stitching after correcting each tile with BaSiC or dye solutions4.

docs.title: Multi-channel viewing
docs.text: Multiple channels can be viewed in a split-screen style. Images are pseudo-colored by default but can be made greyscale. A maximum intensity projection can be done in one click.

docs.title: Stage movement
docs.text:
In addition to using the joystick to control stage movement, the mouse can be used as well. Clicking on a button in the "Live" window will allow you to move by dragging the image.

Focusing can also be done with the scroll wheel, but this is at a set speed1. If PFS is engaged, it will try to fight your focusing attempts.

docs.title: Changing the z-limit
docs.text:
Software z-stage limits are intended to prevent damage to the objectives. However, the default setting does not allow for the dry 4x objective to image deep enough into a plastic multi-well plate. In this case, a temporary and slight tweak to the z-stage limit is allowed.

Changing the z-limit through Elements must be done with on an account with admin rights.

docs.text:
Function Keyboard shortcut Notes Live on the numpad Stop on the numpad Zoom in arrow key Zoom down arrow key Magnifying Glass Press again to enhance contrast Pointer Commonly used to switch back to default behavior after using magnifying glass

  1. While you could change the speed of the scroll wheel through Elements, it's easier to use the joystick controller for course / extra-fine focusing. And you don't mess with the expected behavior for other users. ↩

docs.title: Optical Configurations
docs.text:
Optical Configurations (OCs) are grouped microscope settings. Through OCs, you can tell Elements to "open this shutter; use these filters, set phasers to stun, etc."

Left: Lightpath window. Right: Acquisition window. Animation of switching between OCs to show changing filters and Sola power. The upper turret shutter can also be controlled.

When you acquire images, existing OCs can be modified. The most common modifications to OCs are:

  • Camera exposure time
  • Camera Bit Depth
  • Laser power

docs.title: Lightpaths in NIS-Elements
docs.text: Lightpaths in NIS-Elements are a way to group microscope devices/settings and simplify the Acquisition window by hiding irrelevant components and OCs. If your goal is to look through the eyepieces, there's no need to control the camera or confocal lasers.

docs.title: Eyepieces
docs.text:
When looking through the eyepieces, you'll be on the Eyepieces - DIA or Eyepieces - EPI lightpath and choose an OC.

  • DIA refers to "diascopic" which corresponds here to transmitted light / brightfield
  • EPI refers to "episcopic" which corresponds here to reflected light / epi-fluorescence
Eyepieces - EPI (FITC)Eyepieces - DIA (DIC)

Note

Note how the cameras and spinning disk confocal components are greyed out and inactive in the lightpaths for Eyepieces.

Eyepiece - DIA and Eyepiece - EPI lightpaths are common to both single camera and dual camera modes.

docs.title: Single camera
docs.text:
Because one priority for this scope was dual-camera imaging, the emission filters for single-camera imaging are located in a fast filter wheel right before the "Front Fusion" camera. It contains four single emission filters and has an empty position for brightfield.

Single Camera 405Single Camera 488Single Camera 561Single Camera 640

Note

Both brightfield and fluorescence imaging will be "confocal"1 because the spinning disk can't be moved out of the light path. Light throughput for brightfield is drastically reduced, and the quality of DIC is also impaired.

docs.title: Dual camera
docs.text:
A long pass filter2, which will reflect light below 570nm towards the "Back Fusion BT", is inserted into the TwinCam unit. The back filter wheel has DAPI and FITC emission filters, but the main use-case is simultaneous imaging of green and red fluorophores.

Concerns when using dual camera mode:

  1. Spectral bleed-through
  2. Registration between cameras
  3. Slight (5%) loss in light due to imperfect transmission of the TwinCam DM 2.
Dual Camera 405-561Dual Camera 405-640Dual Camera 488-561Dual Camera 488-640

  1. The spinning disk pattern is optimized for high NA objectives ↩

  2. Semrock Di02-R561 ↩↩

docs.title: ND Acquisition
docs.text:
The ND Acquisition window within NIS-Elements allows users to configure N-Dimensional imaging.

There are five tabs: Time, XY (Multipoint), Large Image (for tiling/stitching), \(\lambda\) (for multiple channels/OCs), and Z.

When multiple dimensions are required, NIS-Elements will default to the fastest order of experiment, but the "Order of Experiment" can be changed.

Options for "Order of Experiment" with the fastest selected by default. Here, a z-stack will be acquired before switching to different channels and finally a large image will be acquired.

docs.title: Time
docs.text:
The Time tab allows for (complex) timelapse imaging.

Tip

  • Close Active Shutter when idle and Switch Transmitted Illuminator off when Idle (0.01 s) should nearly always be enabled.
  • The 1 time loop button is very handy for checking multipoints.

In the figure below, note the two phases: the first is an intentional delay, and the second leads to acquisitions every five seconds for two minutes (25 timepoints/"loops" total).

Time tab in ND Acquisition with two phases.

docs.title: XY (Multipoint)
docs.text:
The XY tab allows for the sequential imaging of multiple points. This can be a great way to increase throughput during timelapse acquisitions. Each location can have its own Z and PFS values.

Warning

  • There is increased light dosage, so the risk of phototoxicity is higher.1
  • If using immersion objectives, the likelihood of stage jitter increases.2

Tip

  • If dealing with an uneven stage (as evidenced by multiple points having PFS values off by 1000s), enabling Include Z should help.
  • Nikon also recommended giving PFS additional time for each point via Wait(0.200000);
  • NIS-Elements can Optimize the order of the points for you to reduce the amount of stage travel
  • Split Multipoints is highly recommended to avoid dealing with one very large .nd2 file.

XY tab in ND Acquisition with three different points and configured for an uneven stage.

docs.title: Large Image (tiling/stitching)
docs.text: The Large Image tab allows for tiling/stitching when what you want to capture requires a larger FOV. Note: there are (better) alternatives that allow for more interactive and flexible ROIs.

docs.title: Channels
docs.text:
The \(\lambda\) or Channels tab allows for multiple OCs to be used in an experiment. An example of a four-color experiment would include imaging DAPI, AF488, AF555, and AF647. Regular brightfield and DIC are also options.

Note

  • Some objectives have a focus (axial) offset between colors. NIS-Elements allows you to correct for this by setting a Focus Offset within the \(\lambda\) tab.

Animation of setting up channels in a preferred order and setting Focus Offsets

docs.title: Z
docs.text:
The Z tab allows for 3-D acquisition/"z-stacks".

Tip

  • The speed of a z-piezo is much greater than the microscope body's focus drive.
  • This scope is equipped with a z-piezo with a travel range of 450 \(\mu\)m

docs.title: Using absolute limits
docs.text: Z-stack limits using absolute limits

docs.title: Using symmetric mode
docs.text:
You may be forced away from using absolute limits because you're using focus offsets or PFS.

Z-stack limits using symmetric mode defined by range (when previously defined using absolute limits)

docs.title: Using asymmetric mode
docs.text:
Asymmetric mode can be helpful if you know you want a set thickness and can set a limit easily. For example, you only want the first X\(\mu\)m from the coverslip or the thickness of tissue sections are known.

Z-stack limits with asymmetric mode defined by range

docs.title: Z device
docs.text:
• I do not recommend using the Focus Drive as the Z Device because it will be much slower than using the piezo.
  • NIDAQ Piezo Z should be slightly more accurate than Triggered NIDAQ Piezo Z at the slight expense of speed.

  1. Even if your multipoints are far from each other, remember that your media can become phototoxic ↩

  2. Oil has inertia. ↩

docs.title: Live-cell emphasis
docs.text:
Nikon Ti2-E with a Yokogawa CSU-X1 spinning disk confocal unit

A motorized Nikon Ti2-E body is matched with a Yokogawa CSU-X1 spinning disk confocal unit for fast and gentle live-cell imaging with a 10x7mm field of view. A Cairn TwinCam unit allows for simultaneous dual-color imaging on two Hamamatsu Fusion BTs (sCMOS cameras with a max QE of 95%), and a piezo stage enables rapid volumetric acquisitions. Four laser lines (405, 488, 561, 640 nm) facilitate flexibility in fluorophores. A stage-top incubation chamber provides a cell-friendly environment of 37°C and 5% CO2, and Nikon’s Perfect Focus System enables long-term imaging without drift. Throughput is increased by imaging multiple locations in between time points. A galvo miniscanner allows for selective photomanipulation and enables FRAP, photocaging, photoactivation, etc.

docs.title: Standard
docs.text:
Nikon Ti2-E with a Yokogawa CSU-X1 spinning disk confocal unit

A motorized Nikon Ti2-E body is matched with a Yokogawa CSU-X1 spinning disk confocal unit for fast imaging. A Hamamatsu Fusion BT (sCMOS camera with a max QE of 95% with an ultra-quiet low read noise mode), and a piezo stage enables rapid volumetric acquisitions with a 10x7mm field of view. Tiling + stitching is possible with flexible region selection options. Four laser lines (405, 488, 561, 640 nm) facilitate flexibility in fluorophores. Six objectives--from a dry 4x to an oil 100x/1.49 NA Apo TIRF--permit imaging at all scales.

docs.title: Shutting down
docs.text:
1. Close NIS-Elements and wait about 10 seconds before turning off the scope body.
  2. Ensure the objectives are lowered all the way down
  3. Turn off scope body (before moving to next step, wait for light show/beeping to finish)
  4. Turn off X1 unit by rotating key counterclockwise
  5. Turn off controller for microscope
  6. Turn off laser box by rotating key counterclockwise
  7. Turn off surge protector (side switch)
  8. Cover the microscope

If you want to sync your data on the PSH network drive immediately, go to the computer Desktop and double-click on "BACKUP-X1". A black window will show up and automatically close when finished backing up the files.

docs.title: Shutting down (live-cell)
docs.text:
• Turn off the Tokai Hit unit by pushing the orange button.
  • Close the Apollo valve for CO2 by rotating clockwise 90 degrees until the yellow handle is perpendicular to the tubing.
  • Lower the objective as far as it'll go.
  • Turn off the Bioptechs controller by pushing the On/Off button
  • Remove the Bioptechs objective warmer and set back in box.
  • Remove stage top incubator lid and set on air table.
  • Remove water from reservoir using a syringe, and deposit into glass beaker labelled "waste".
  • When no more water can be removed using the syringe, switch to using a KimWipe to soak up the remaining water.
  • Inspect your sample adapter for oil (and clean if needed).
  • See normal shut-down procedures

docs.title: Start-up
docs.text:
1. Turn on surge protector (switch on the right)
  2. Turn on laser box "F XL" by rotating key clockwise
  3. Turn on microscope controller (white Nikon box to right of laser box)
  4. Turn on CSU-X1 unit (connected to the left port of microscope) by rotating key clockwise

  5. Uncover and turn on scope body by pushing a switch on the right side of the scope at the back. (1)

    1. Sometimes the scope doesn't turn on properly. You'll know this is the case if it starts beeping and/or the joystick pad doesn't light up. Don't worry--just shut off the scope body (wait for the beeps to finish), and try starting again.

  6. Sit at computer and start NIS-Elements by double-clicking on the NIS-Elements AR icon.

  7. Select your account from the drop-down menu (default: no password).
  8. Choose Front Fusion for single-camera imaging or Dual Fusion for dual-camera imaging.
  9. Check the drawer to see the TwinCam DM's status. Ensure it's out for single-camera imaging and in for dual-camera imaging.

"Front Fusion" / single camera mode highlighted

Video showing start-up steps 1-5

docs.title: Allow CO2 flow and start Tokai Hit unit
docs.text:
• Open the Apollo valve for CO2 by rotating counter-clockwise 90 degrees until the yellow handle is parallel to the tubing.
Photo of CO2 line
  • Turn on the Tokai Hit incubator control box by pushing the orange button
  • Check the airflow indicator and ensure the ball is at the 150 ML/MIN line

docs.title: Objective Heater (only for immersion objectives!)
docs.text:
Bioptechs Objective Heater with labels
  • Remove the stage adapter for easier access.
  • Turn on the Bioptechs Controller by pushing the Power On/Off Button on the bottom right.
  • Take the Bioptechs Objective Heater out of its protective case.
  • Loosen the heater band by turning counter-clockwise with either a 5/64 or 2mm Allen driver
  • Give more slack to the monofilament tail by pushing on the button and feeding the monofilament loop through
  • Carefully move the objective heater towards the objectives by going underneath the motorized stage.
  • A blue LED will indicate that the heating band is not heating. Secure the objective heater by the heating band with slow clockwise turns (using the 5/64 or 2mm Allen driver) of the screw labelled "Heater Band Adjustment. Do not overtighten--as soon as the blue LED shuts off, stop turning.
  • For securing the monofilament loop, press the button until it depresses and then gently pull on the monofilament loop.
  • Adjust the correction collar.
  • Add a drop of Nikon Type F immersion oil to the objective.

docs.title: Set-up Tokai Hit stage-top incubator
docs.text:
• Ensure the Tokai Hit stage adapter is installed (do not overtighten the screws!)
  • Put the Tokai Hit stage top incubator onto the stage while lifting the cables/tubing with your right hand to prevent undesirable tension on the cables/tubing.
  • Add 20mL of distilled/DI water to the reservoir
  • Inspect the sample adapter for oil (and clean if needed) before inserting into the Tokai Hit stage top incubator.
  • Insert your sample (or a clean dish/slide), and attach the Tokai Hit dish/slide lid. Make sure the magnetic lid is flat or your sample will be tilted.
  • If using an immersion objective, raise the objectives so that the oil and the bottom of the dish make contact.
  • Put the stage top incubator lid on.
  • Turn off lights, and close the door to the microscope room.

Important

  • Wait >60 minutes for temperatures to stabilize before imaging.
  • If using dual camera acquisition, please see Dual Camera Alignment for next steps.

docs.title: Tips and tricks to get the most out of your imaging
Clean your coverslips before putting them on the scope
docs.text:
Example

1. Dirty coverslips after mounting

2. After cleaning with water, the coverslip on the right still shows residue

3. After wiping with EtOH and glass cleaner, coverslips are clean

Keep coverslips centered as much as possible.

  • If coverslips are too close to the edge, your coverslip may be un-imageable.
  • Coverslips close to the edge also increase the risk of the objective hitting a stage insert.

docs.title: Beware of photobleaching
docs.text:
Don't expose your sample to any more light than absolutely necessary.

  • Use the least amount of SOLA/laser power needed and close the shutter when not needed.
  • Set z-limits and/or multi-point positions using an OC with low laser power.
  • Doubling the laser power more than doubles the potential for photobleaching.

docs.title: Avoid mounting media with DAPI/Hoechst
docs.text:
• Both DAPI and Hoechst photoconvert with UV light into green-emitting and red-emitting forms.
  • There'll be increased background (noticeable on widefield but not as much on confocal)

docs.title: Know where your objective is at all times
docs.text:
• Have an idea of the rough z-position for your sample and keep an eye on the z-position (preferably using the joystick pad display).
  • Make sure you aren't at risk of hitting the stage (insert) with the objective.

docs.title: Lower immersion objectives if switching between wells or coverslips
docs.text: • To prevent possible objective lens damage, either use the Escape functionality or lower the objectives manually

docs.title: Focusing on your sample
docs.text:
• Ensure that the stage insert and sample are positioned and secured properly.
  • If using oil immersion objectives, raise the objective while watching for oil contact.
  • Use the eyepieces when finding your sample.

Avoid objective lens damage during focusing

One easy way to damage objectives is to raise them too high. The risk is not only to the objective that you're using--but also for the adjacent ones since they can hit the stage.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Microscope does not turn on properly

This can be heard (by the microscope beeping) and also seen (by the joystick pad not turning on). Solution: Turn off the microscope body and turn on again. It should work within three tries.

Parts of the microscope don't respond to Elements

Solution: Try restarting the software and microscope body.

Elements crashed and FRAP doesn't work any more

Solution: The microscope body must be power cycled in addition to restarting Elements.

Switching between OCs takes a while

If OCs have different camera settings (e.g. readout mode or bit-depth BUT NOT EXPOSURE TIME), it takes a long time for the camera to change settings.

Can't see blue or green signal through computer in single-camera mode

Check to see if the TwinCam dichroic mirror is in. If it is, remove it.

Removing the TwinCam cover reveals that the dichroic mirror is in

docs.title: Common Pitfalls
docs.text:
Do not place coverslips too close to the edge.

Coverslips too close to the edge will be troublesome, especially if using immersion objectives.

Do not get close to the stage insert edge during live imaging with immersion objectives if you want multipoints
